163960874.review:
Counter-Strike 2 - A Pale Imitation:
In stark contrast to the brilliance of CS:GO, Counter-Strike 2 pales in comparison, failing to capture the essence of its predecessor or offer anything new or innovative to the franchise. From its lackluster gameplay to its uninspired design, Counter-Strike 2 feels like a half-hearted attempt to cash in on the success of its predecessor rather than a genuine effort to push the series forward.

One of the most glaring flaws of Counter-Strike 2 is its lack of depth and complexity. Compared to the finely tuned mechanics of CS:GO, Counter-Strike 2 feels simplistic and shallow, with gameplay that fails to engage or excite players. The gunplay lacks the precision and satisfaction of its predecessor, with weapons feeling unbalanced and uninspired. Additionally, the game's map design is lackluster and uninspired, offering little in the way of strategic depth or tactical nuance.

Furthermore, Counter-Strike 2 suffers from a lack of innovation and creativity. Rather than building upon the foundation laid by CS:GO, the game feels like a rehash of tired ideas and stale concepts. There is a distinct lack of innovation in both gameplay mechanics and content, leaving players feeling underwhelmed and disappointed.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, the disparity between Counter-Strike: Global Offensive and Counter-Strike 2 is glaring and undeniable. While CS:GO stands as a shining example of excellence in the world of tactical shooters, Counter-Strike 2 languishes in the shadows, unable to capture the magic of its predecessor or offer anything new or innovative to the franchise. CS:GO's strategic depth, balanced gameplay, and thriving esports scene set it apart as a true masterpiece of the genre, while Counter-Strike 2 fades into obscurity as a forgettable footnote in the franchise's history.

163896590.review:
My child hasn't eaten a meal in weeks. I've gambled away his college fund on those cases, all the while assuring him that a big win is just around the corner. But deep down, I'm aware it's nothing but wishful thinking. I've jeopardized my son's future with my fixation on the game, yet I can't seem to shake this habit.

Each night, I find myself in tears, watching those case opening videos, grappling with regret and what-ifs. I'm not seeking sympathy; I'm sharing my story in the hopes that it might resonate with someone out there.

So, take heed: gambling can lead down a treacherous path. It's a hard lesson I'm learning firsthand. Don't let the allure blindside you like it did me. It's a cautionary tale worth heeding.

163836064.review:
As much as I love this game the CS2 from CSGO update just makes the game feel.... lesser?

I love the engine update in an off itself; I think the game feels better and the graphical update is also nice, and the new smokes shifts the game up in a way that doesn't clash with the original gameplay while solving some of my biggest issues with it. 

That being said the new loadout system annoys the hell out of me; I still to this day do not udnerstand why we can't just have all weapons in the weaponwheel, and instead have to replace the guns. It feels like rock,paper,scissiors where you have to live with the consequences for the rest of the match because there absolutely have been times where I've been like "Damn I could use a negev for holding down this choke during save, but I got it out of the wheel because I use it so rarely." It also essentially removes some of the less popular weapons from the game because when in the world are you gonna be rocking the M249 in your loadout?

Also the lack of maps; I'm sorry but CSGO had been slowly hiding away tons of maps and CS2 continues that trend. Where's Lake, Safehouse, Monastery, Agency, Bank, Train, Cache, Canals, Cobble, Sugarcane, Militia etc? I get that a ton of these weren't "competitive" but removing them? Nah. The game feels stale despite the gameplay changes. Maps where the main thing that offered difference in your gameplay experience and the smaller map-pool can be really felt when I look at the matchmaking and feel; "I am not feeling any of these rn"

It's just such a shame that for what otherwise was such a nice update we've lost SO much. Workshop is thankfully slowly filling up with map ports but idk, as much as I adore Counter Strike it just feels... lesser now. While I know some of the maps will of course make it back I doubt the full roster will ever return. 

I still "recommend it" as it is the best of its kind imo, but just know that tons of stuff is missing and as someone who's been playing the game on and off for 10 years now it just stings.

163800503.review:
In the neon-lit labyrinth of cyberspace, where digital echoes of countless battles reverberate, there exists a game like no other: Fragged Realities. Its allure is magnetic, drawing in players from all corners of the globe with promises of adrenaline-fueled chaos and unfathomable challenges.

At first glance, it seems like any other online shooter – guns, bombs, knives, and skins – all the ingredients for a virtual warzone. But beneath the surface lies a world teeming with its own unique ecosystem of players and perils.

Meet Alex, an unsuspecting gamer lured into the fray by the siren song of Fragged Realities. With each match, he plunges deeper into the rabbit hole, encountering a menagerie of adversaries and allies. Among them are the enigmatic Russians, with their terse commands and lightning reflexes, the elusive hackers who bend the rules of the game to their will, and the smurfs, masters of disguise who lurk in the shadows, ready to strike.

But the true heart of Fragged Realities lies not in its mechanics, but in its community – a motley crew of players bound together by their shared love-hate relationship with the game. From the camaraderie of battle-scarred veterans to the venomous barbs of toxic teammates, every interaction shapes Alex's journey through the digital battlefield.

As he navigates the tumultuous waters of Fragged Realities, Alex finds himself on a quest not just for victory, but for understanding. Through the crucible of conflict, he learns new languages – Russian, Turkish, Portuguese, Arabic – and discovers a lexicon of profanity and slang unique to the game. Cyka, blyat, noob, kurwa – each word a badge of honor, a testament to his perseverance in the face of adversity.

But for every triumph, there is a setback. For every moment of glory, a crushing defeat. Alex rages, he cries, he uninstalls, he reinstalls, trapped in an endless cycle of addiction and frustration. And yet, through it all, he cannot deny the allure of Fragged Realities – a game that consumes him, heart and soul.

In the end, perhaps that is the truest testament to its greatness. For despite its flaws, despite its challenges, Fragged Realities endures, a beacon of chaos in an ever-changing digital landscape. Love it or hate it, play it or leave it – the choice is yours. But one thing is certain: once you enter the world of Fragged Realities, you can never truly escape.

163733848.review:
Counter-Strike 2 (CS2) is a highly acclaimed first-person shooter that continues to captivate players with its intense gameplay and strategic depth. Developed by Valve Corporation, this sequel to the iconic Counter-Strike franchise delivers a compelling experience for both new players and seasoned veterans.

Gameplay:
CS2 maintains the core gameplay mechanics that made its predecessors so popular. Players choose between terrorists and counter-terrorists, each with distinct objectives. Whether it's defusing bombs, rescuing hostages, or eliminating the opposing team, every round requires precision, teamwork, and quick reflexes. The tactical depth of CS2 is unmatched, offering a variety of weapons, equipment, and strategies to employ.

Graphics and Sound:
Visually, CS2 impresses with detailed environments, realistic weapon models, and smooth animations. The sound design adds to the immersion, with authentic weapon sounds, footsteps, and ambient effects that enhance the atmosphere of intense firefights.

Maps and Modes:
CS2 features a diverse selection of maps set in various locations around the world. Each map presents unique challenges and strategic opportunities, keeping gameplay fresh and engaging. The game offers a range of modes, including classic bomb defusal, hostage rescue, and team deathmatch, catering to different playstyles and preferences.

Community and Competitiveness:
One of CS2's strengths is its vibrant community and competitive scene. Players can participate in ranked matchmaking, tournaments, and community events, showcasing their skills and competing for recognition on leaderboards. The active community also ensures a steady stream of updates, patches, and new content, keeping the game dynamic and evolving.

Potential Drawbacks:
While CS2 excels in many areas, it's not without its flaws. Newcomers may find the learning curve steep, especially when facing experienced players. Toxicity within the community, including cheating and negative behavior, can also detract from the overall experience for some players.

Conclusion:
Counter-Strike 2 remains a cornerstone of the FPS genre, offering fast-paced action, strategic depth, and a thriving competitive community. Its combination of tactical gameplay, diverse maps, and competitive modes ensures lasting appeal for fans of shooters. While challenges exist, the overall experience of CS2 is undeniably exhilarating, making it a must-play for anyone seeking intense multiplayer action.

163658455.review:
I love counter strike, however the linux build is currently unplayable... I can't get over 30fps on CS2 even with high end hardware and optimal drivers, but I can run cyberpunk just fine with raytracing. The hitreg is really hit or miss depending on what server I'm connected to, sometimes I can hit shots just like I did in CS:GO and sometimes I need to aim a foot to the left of people to hit them? I had to resort to playing on a virtual machine with gpu passthrough which gets 3x the fps of the native build for linux but still has the same hitreg issues. Also the linux build has an issue where you can see people firing guns through walls which last I checked was still unpatched, Not like the info will make much difference at 30fps.

I do have faith that in future updates linux compatibility will get better considering I got far better fps on linux with CS:GO than I did with windows prior to CS2.

For anyone playing on linux I'd recommend setting up hardware passthrough and continuing to play in a kvm virtual machine (If you only use linux), if not then I guess just use windows.

Hopefully Valve can fix some of these issues once the cheater problem is solved :)

*Will update review once linux compatability is restored*

163621796.review:
Wow... where should I even start? CS2 is like the cringe fest you never knew you needed in your life! From the moment I fired up the game, I was hit with a wave of nostalgia... and embarrassment.

Let's talk graphics. It's like someone took a time machine back to the 90s and decided, "Hey, let's make everything look like it's made of pixels!" But you know what? It weirdly works. It's like staring into the abyss of outdated graphics and finding a strange kind of beauty in it.

And the sound effects? Oh boy. It's like a symphony of cringe-inducing noises that make you question your life choices. From the overly dramatic explosions to the cheesy voice acting, every sound in CS2 is a masterpiece of awkwardness.

But wait, there's more! Let's talk about the storyline. It's like the writers took every cliché from every B-list action movie ever made and mashed them together into one glorious mess. You've got your generic hero, your evil villain with a questionable accent, and of course, the damsel in distress who can't seem to do anything without the hero's help.

And don't even get me started on the gameplay. It's like trying to navigate through a maze blindfolded while juggling flaming swords. It's frustrating, it's confusing, but somehow... it's addicting.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game that will make you cringe so hard you'll feel it in your soul, then CS2 is the game for you. Just make sure to have a bottle of eye bleach and a therapist on standby. You're gonna need it.

163590897.review:
is good Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS:GO) has solidified its place as one of the most iconic and enduring multiplayer first-person shooters of all time. Developed by Valve Corporation and Hidden Path Entertainment, this iteration of the legendary Counter-Strike series brings together refined gameplay mechanics, intense tactical engagements, and a thriving competitive scene that continues to captivate players worldwide.

Gameplay (9/10):
CS:GO's gameplay is a masterclass in the FPS genre. The core mechanics are simple yet deep, emphasizing teamwork, strategy, and skill. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer, the game offers something for everyone, thanks to its accessible yet challenging gameplay. Matches are fast-paced and adrenaline-fueled, demanding quick reflexes, precise aim, and clever tactics to outsmart opponents. The variety of weapons, maps, and game modes ensures that no two matches feel the same, keeping the experience fresh and engaging.

Graphics and Sound (8/10):
While CS:GO's graphics may not push the boundaries of realism, they remain functional and polished, with clean visuals that prioritize performance over flashy effects. The character models and weapon designs are well-crafted, allowing for easy identification of friend and foe amidst the chaos of battle. The sound design is equally impressive, with realistic weapon sounds and environmental effects that enhance immersion and situational awareness. However, some players may find the visuals a bit dated compared to more recent titles in the genre.

Community and Esports (10/10):
CS:GO's community is vibrant and dedicated, comprising millions of players from all walks of life. Whether you're looking to team up with friends for casual matches or compete at the highest levels of competitive play, there's always a place for you in the CS:GO community. The game's robust matchmaking system ensures fair and balanced matches, while the active player base ensures quick queue times and plenty of opponents to test your skills against.

Furthermore, CS:GO's esports scene is second to none, with major tournaments drawing in millions of viewers and offering lucrative prize pools. The game's competitive integrity, combined with its spectator-friendly gameplay, makes it a staple of the esports landscape and a must-watch for fans of competitive gaming.

Overall (9/10):
Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a timeless classic that continues to stand the test of time. Its addictive gameplay, thriving community, and legendary esports scene make it a must-play for any fan of the FPS genre. While its graphics may not be cutting-edge and its learning curve can be steep, the rewards of mastering its mechanics are well worth the investment. Whether you're a casual player looking for some fun with friends or a competitive gamer aiming for esports glory, CS:GO offers something for everyone, making it a true modern classic.

163590761.review:
While "Counter-Strike 2" isn't a real game as of my last update, it's possible to explore hypothetical reasons why a sequel to Counter-Strike, a highly popular and influential first-person shooter, might be considered the "best game ever" by some:

Refinement of Gameplay: Counter-Strike has a simple yet highly strategic gameplay loop that involves teamwork, tactics, and skill. A sequel could refine these mechanics, offering even tighter controls, more balanced gameplay, and enhanced graphics.
Expanded Content: A sequel could introduce new maps, weapons, game modes, and customization options, providing players with fresh experiences while still maintaining the core elements that made the original so beloved.
Community Engagement: Counter-Strike has a passionate and dedicated community that creates custom maps, mods, and other content. A sequel could foster even greater community involvement, potentially integrating user-generated content more seamlessly into the game.
Competitive Scene: Counter-Strike has a thriving esports scene, with tournaments attracting millions of viewers and offering substantial prize pools. A sequel could further support the competitive aspect of the game, introducing features designed specifically for esports and competitive play.
Technical Advancements: With advances in technology, a sequel could leverage new hardware capabilities to deliver more immersive visuals, smoother gameplay, and innovative features that were not possible in the original game.
Nostalgia and Legacy: For fans of the original Counter-Strike, a sequel could evoke feelings of nostalgia while also introducing the franchise to a new generation of players, building upon the legacy of one of the most iconic shooters in gaming history.
These are just a few potential reasons why a hypothetical "Counter-Strike 2" could be considered the "best game ever" by some players. Ultimately, what makes a game the "best" is highly subjective and varies from person to person based on their preferences and experiences.

I love this game. Played a ton several years ago, lost access to that account, but now years later I feel pulled back. However, I cannot recommend this game in its current state. I think some of the things they have done with CS2 vs csgo are incredible, such as the smokes, the graphics, etc. However, there are a few glaring issues:

1) The cheaters. Even having prime with never cheating, and even though this account only has around 400 hrs and the trust factor may not be incredible, it shouldn't be this bad. Nearly every game is just hvh. And since its me and my non cheating friends vs hackers, its just a lose simulator. Compounding this is that you can't surrender without a teammate abandoning, which will automatically lose them a ton of elo (more that if we were to just lose) and so you have to sit through the whole game while they b hop to your spawn and kill you while shooting faster than should be possible. And as for getting the hackers banned? Yeah, good one. Accounts that were blatant (bhops, walls, aim, etc) that I faced months ago are still going strong. Reporting does nothing. Vac live is a joke. 

2) Lack of content compared to CSGO. CS2 hasn't had an operation, it lacks a ton of maps and gamemodes, the community server browser is ass, and on top of that you can't even host a custom map/server with friends to play that lost content without going through a bunch of port forwarding, which wasn't necessary in csgo. 

There are other complaints I could go into, such as subtick vs 128 tick, valve's greed with skins, replacing csgo vs just creating a new store page for cs2, or a whole host of issues, but I think that the two I went into more detail on are the main problems that prevent me from recommending the game. Its a shame because I still have fond memories of the game and I want really really bad for it to be good.

Valve please fix

Despite what you may hear about this game from spazzers and youtubers, the Valve dev team has done something truly innovative with this game.  No amount of flashy gimmicks can make up for lack of depth in Counter-strike's competition. 
With the addition of volumetric smoke grenades, the game has become even more nuanced.  The game is 20 years old and Valve hasn't stopped.  Valve continues to innovate, while their "competition" continues to mindlessly spit out cookie cutter slop.  You can't blame those guys, they are a product of their work culture.  GabeN continues to innovate, while everyone else duct tapes RGB lights onto their gold spray painted shopping carts.  
If you want a deep game without the gimmicks, and real substance, this is the game.  Great for all players.
The best FPS by a long shot.

163414095.review:
Counter Strike 2, ah, where do I even begin? It's like diving into a kaleidoscope of digital euphoria, a symphony of pixels dancing in the ether of cyberspace. From the moment you click that icon and plunge into its enigmatic world, you're whisked away on a journey of... well, let's call it cosmic ambiguity.

Firstly, let's talk about the graphics. Oh, the graphics! They're like a technicolor dreamcoat woven by the digital deities themselves. Each pixel, meticulously placed, seems to whisper secrets of a universe beyond comprehension. It's as if the game world exists in a state of perpetual flux, a perpetual dance of light and shadow that defies explanation.

And the sound design! Ah, the sound design! It's like being serenaded by a chorus of celestial beings, their voices echoing through the vast expanse of the digital cosmos. Every gunshot, every footstep, every whispered utterance is a symphony unto itself, a cacophony of auditory ecstasy that transcends mortal understanding.

But let's not forget about the gameplay! Oh, the gameplay! It's like trying to solve a Rubik's Cube while riding a unicycle on a tightrope suspended over a pit of lava. Every movement, every decision, every fleeting thought is fraught with peril and possibility. It's a delicate balance of skill and strategy, a delicate dance of death that leaves you breathless and exhilarated.



In conclusion, Counter Strike 2 is a masterpiece of digital artistry, a masterpiece of existential ambiguity that defies explanation. It's a journey into the unknown, a journey into the depths of the human soul that leaves you questioning everything you thought you knew. So, grab your mouse and keyboard, and prepare to embark on a journey unlike any other.

163396316.review:
The use of cheats in CS 2 is a significant issue that makes the game unpleasant and creates an unfair competitive environment. Existing anti-cheat systems are not always 100% effective. This proposal introduces a new anti-cheat system that could significantly reduce cheating.

The proposed system is inspired by the Inspector System in CS:GO. Inspectors will be able to watch matches live, preventing information leaks by monitoring the game 2-3 rounds behind. There will be 10 inspectors per match, and if at least 8 inspectors vote that cheating is occurring, the match will be canceled, and the cheater will be penalized. This system has several advantages: faster and more accurate cheat detection, fewer false alarms, and community involvement. However, the disadvantages include difficulty in finding inspectors, inspector training, and inspector abuse.

The Live Inspector System has the potential to significantly reduce cheating. Despite its drawbacks, its advantages outweigh them. It is recommended that Valve consider integrating the system. Additionally, efforts should be made to establish criteria for becoming an inspector and to develop tools for monitoring inspector performance and detecting cheats.

The integration of this system into CS:GO 2 will substantially reduce cheating and make the game fairer and more enjoyable.

(I recommend the game so that my recommendation goes to the top)

Thanks, best regards.

163359208.review:
An enjoyable game with a simple concept that's difficult to master. Has a community that wants to continually improve the experience (workshop maps, weapons, stickers, etc.). The competitive aspect and professional scene provide a lot of entertainment and interaction with people around the world.

Despite replacing CSGO, I understand that CS2 isn't supposed to be a one-to-one. It means that some core gameplay differs, but at times it can be difficult to determine if certain changes are intentional. Updates have seemed to bring gradual improvements, so this game has the opportunity to surpass CSGO; nailing the gameplay should be one of the main priorities.

However, the game would greatly benefit from a basic anticheat that detects spinbotting, wallhacking, aimlocking, and XP boosting lobbies. This is the most glaring negative since it occurs in every game mode and shouldn't be tolerated. Reporting players in-game and via the player's Steam profile doesn't seem to do much as no confirmation is received as to whether appropriate action has taken place. Hoping that one day I'll be able to return to this review to say its frequency has dramatically reduced.

Stages of Playing CS2:
 1. trying the game for free, get blasted by cheaters all the time but you still like the game
2. discovering that steam will give free weekly drops and competitive matches by buying prime, it's a good idea since you're not going to deal with cheaters anymore.
3. buying prime and getting kicked from every competitive match for beign a noob.
4. you'll start watching theWarOwl to be good (i highly recommend it's the best cs channel) and training in AimBotz workshop map.
5. you're actually winning good job but you always get trashed on by toxic players...
6. muting and ignoring toxic players, a new level of peace in cs discovered
7. you'll meet good friends and make a team to play Premier, you'll start grinding
8. you discover skin trading and case opening...
9. now YOU'RE ADDICTED to CS2 

Review: perfect competitive game, even if you're a skin collector you'll enjoy this game because you can always sell your skins unlike most of online games, but cheaters are becoming a huge issue in cs2 hope it will get fixed

Tip: to minimize queuing with cheaters keep in mind that this game has a trust factor you can learn about it in the Official Steam page

163086833.review: This game is great but there all multiple things keeping it from being amazing. I started playing a few months ago and I would say I am addicted to the game loop and satisfaction of clicking heads. It is also a lot of fun to play with friends, at least when were not bickering at each other or playing like crap. I also love the skins and how unique the trading system is, hopefully that doesn't get messed up by valve. However there is a massive problem in the game that is of course the cheaters. Out of every game I play among all the different platforms, this game is by far the worst game when it comes to cheating and its not even close. It genuinely blows my mind how many people cheat at this game, I would honestly say like maybe 30-35% of people are cheating and I feel like that's being generous. I could go on a tangent describing the types of games I've played and cheaters I've encountered, but I know this is getting long already so I'll just say that FaceIt's anti-cheat works so if you're fed up with cheaters in premier or competitive then head over there. I don't know what valve's solution to the cheaters should be given there's so many and in every rank and every mode and it feels like there's nothing you can do as a normal player to get them off the platform. At the end of the day valve will have to address this problem head on with a better VAC. But on a brighter note, I have met a bunch of cool people from playing this game and I do have fun playing it. For that I am recommending it. I also feel like more people playing the game will maybe thin out the cheaters. It's not a bad game, it just needs to be tended to and taken care of and in the right ways. I can't honestly say how much faith I have in valve but I do really hope for the best. This game has potential to last many more decades as long as they take care of it.

Title: Urgent Call for Anti-Cheat Enhancements in CS2!

Review (as of April 2024):
As an avid player of Counter-Strike, it is disheartening to witness the persistent cheating issues that continue to plague the game’s competitive integrity. Over the past few months, the community across various platforms—including Reddit, Twitter, Twitch, and YouTube—has voiced serious concerns regarding the prevalence of cheaters, particularly in Premier and Matchmaking modes.

Despite the community's ongoing efforts to bring these issues to light, there seems to be a noticeable lack of effective countermeasures from Valve to address the situation. The absence of a robust anti-cheat system not only undermines the gameplay experience but also discourages fair play among the user base.

In light of these challenges, I urge the developers at Valve to prioritize the implementation of a more stringent anti-cheat system. Enhancing these measures would not only improve the competitive environment but also restore trust and satisfaction among your dedicated players. We appreciate the complexity of this issue, but a focused effort to combat cheating is essential for the longevity and success of CS2.

162910373.review:
No longer playable, unfortunately. Had the game for a while, played here and there over the years, but now it's just gotten to the point of no return. Free-to-play lobbies weren't so bad minus the occasional cheater or mismatched professional, so I thought I'd get Prime for the free cases and maybe become more interested in the game.
Yeah, no. First match I got kicked for no discernible reason, but before I was gone I took a look and saw everyone there was practically a player for an e-sports team. Decorated profiles, loads of expensive skins, and zero patience for mediocre players. Tried another match, similar results.
If I knew this was what Prime meant, I would've never bought it. I've been trying to get better bit by bit, but thanks to Prime my only opponents are Master Rank I's and higher while I'm hardly a Silver I. This is the most unfriendly and infuriating competitive scene I've witnessed in a while, and I wholeheartedly regret this.

So, as a message to anyone who may be wanting to get into this as a new player:

Don't.

DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME UNLESS; you are a sadist or into BDSM! 

Why you might ask?
In my last game we had a cheater on the other team, and people will ask how do we know that they are cheating. To This i ask, how good can you Bhop across the map and head shot everyone through walls in seconds while spinning at the same time?

If you do not know what i am talking about;

i) Bunny hop (Bhop) [legit]/ AUTO/Assisted-Bhop [cheat] - a form of movement to increase ones speed by hitting jumps that will accelerate ones velocity in the game

ii) Aim bot - to use external applications that allow for the adjustment of ones aim to consistently hit the desired target with out fail. 

iii) Anti AIM (AA) - to offset the visible character model from the hit-box model.

iv)Walls - to have the ability to see players through materiel that is not transparent.

v) !!!! Spin bot !!!!- to combine all 4 into one category and spin.

In my last two game writing this review, both had Spin-Bots. This game is broken, and you will see a cheater in almost every game. 

For those who do not believe that there are cheater everywhere and say that i'm not good or that they are just better i will bestow apon you information that will make you doubt every interaction until you properly review a game.
Various Cheats can allow for adjustments. what do i mean by this? Well, because of how advanced cheats have become cheaters/ hackers/ script kitty's can apply functions to there cheats. Intern creating subcategory of said cheats!

Some Variation examples: 1)AIM Bots, 2) Walls 3) Other or tools
1.1) Soft aim - to apply aim assistance once the cross air/ target reaches a set distance from the target (can apply a 360 degree)
1.2) Low FOV aim assist - like soft aim but you need to have the target in sight
1.3) Mag dependent Aim - Aim assist will not toggle "ON" unless a specific bullet(s) or amount are shot.
1.4) Body Aim lock - you can adjust were your aim will lock and the intensity of said aim; Aim bot is not always set for the head and can be body parts like arms, legs, groin, chest etc.
2.1) Radar - to show the location of all players (including the enemy) on ones mini map
2.2) Distance specific walls - Walls but the player need to be in a specified distance
2.3) Cross air lines - to show the line of ones gun allowing you to know if one is aiming or holding and area/angle
2.4) utility walls - to only display ones weapon or device that is being held through walls
2.5) Ping location walls - to ping the location of the enemy without line of sight.
3.1) Toggle - to set a switch or key to turn ON or OFF the cheat; applys to everything aim, walls, etc
3.2) open all chat - allows you to see all communication in chat box
3.3) display teams purchases - lets you see what the enemy have bought 
3.4) graphical change - allows the for manipulation of texture for character model, sky, map, etc
3.5) Third person perspective - (name says it all)
3.6) List spectators - allows one to see who is viewing them; this is often used too let the cheater know when to toggle off so that they are not suspected of cheating
3.7) Utill presets/ projections - allows / shows where to throw utill at the desired location

etc

As you can see cheaters are not stupid (alot of them are tho), and  they will try to hide the cheats. But just because you are bad at the game dose not mean you should cheat, just because everyone else is cheat dose not mean you should cheat. 

Because of the huge influx of cheaters, i can not even play a game without a spin-bot'er or closet-cheater (someone who try's to hide there cheats) playing alongside or against me. It is frustrating because cheaters tip the scale of ranks. I have seen many players who are lacking in so much game knowledge and understanding in my ranks and above wondering how they even got here, just to find out that they were cheating. 

Just imagine you work at a nuclear power plant just to find out that the person responsible for your safety and the facility safety are not even qualified for that position. Everything would go boom or the rest of the team would need to compensate for this said persons incompetence.

VALVE please Fix! This as it has retched comedic levels.
Note, I'm not even laughing!

162814732.review:
Played CS:GO last time actively in 2016. Decided to come back for a lack of interest in other games and I gotta say what a sorry state this is in.
-Server issues in nearly every match makes competitive (premier) matches a disconnected mess, having both sides exhausting their timeouts within the first 5 or so rounds. After that many have to spectate multiple rounds in succession if they get unlucky.
There's a massive surge in cheaters currently with the recent game updates, allowing you to use console commands that e.g. make smokes invisible, terrain invisible and entity (players and chickens) hitboxes be seen through walls. Just to name a few.
Security is terrible. You can report a plain cheater in a premier match and they still haven't been banned a week after. This is partly due to 'overwatch' (CS:GO's long-running anti-cheater system) not being a thing anymore (...yet?).

Really want to return and grind again like I did nearly 8 years ago, but when every match gives you a sour taste in mouth it's very hard to enjoy it.

Volvo, please fix

Have played since CSS. The game is literally devolving in front of our very eyes. Cheaters are absolutely the thing that is destroying this game. I know I am not v.s. a cheater in every match, but even 1 cheater every 10 games (high trust factor) is absurd. 3rd party apps say im vs 100 aim players. CS2 is just not playable right now due to the inept anticheat, even in competitive and casual modes. People seem to just be hacking because they know it wont get punished, where they buy alt accounts and just hack with their friends because its edgy. I will say this- after playing more than 1500 matches since release, 3 people have been banned in those games. Blatant spinners I have faced months ago are still unbanned. What is going on???

The game is no longer a haven for competitive, fair gunplay. There are other games to offer that, and although the game is fun, I cannot recommend it at all right now. Play something else.

Cheaters. That’s all this game is about currently. Playing against cheaters in nearly every match, cheating accusations and paranoia about cheaters, cheater streamers, and talking about cheating online. Well, everyone is talking about it online except Valve who has been radio silent. Zero communication. The game is in a sad state now which detracts from the core game which would be fun otherwise. Even when someone is blatantly spinbotting and everyone reports them and kicks them from the match you'll see them again the next day doing the same thing. There is no anti-cheat and no repercussions for cheating. Apparently Valve has no plan to address this because the game makes too much money for them as-is.

Update nearly 20 game hours later: It's gotten worse. Straight-up blatant cheating with no attempt to hide it even in casual games and against bots. It's ridiculous. Beyond the blatant cheating like aimbotting it's obvious many people have wallhacks on when spectated. I'm starting to believe we'll see Half-life 3 before VAC gets fixed and re-enabled.

162684047.review:
Counter-Strike 2: Evolved Warfare is not just a sequel; it's a transformation. Building upon the solid foundation laid by its predecessor, Counter-Strike 2 takes the classic gameplay experience to new heights, delivering an adrenaline-fueled rush that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

One of the most striking aspects of Counter-Strike 2 is its visual overhaul. The graphics are nothing short of breathtaking, with meticulously detailed environments, lifelike character models, and stunning special effects that immerse players in the heart of the action. From the gritty streets of urban warfare to the sprawling landscapes of exotic locales, every map is a work of art, offering both beauty and tactical depth.

But it's not just about looks; Counter-Strike 2 also introduces a wealth of new gameplay features that enhance the overall experience. From advanced weapon customization options to dynamic weather effects that impact gameplay, every match feels fresh and unpredictable. The addition of new game modes, including the pulse-pounding Battle Royale, adds even more variety to the mix, ensuring that players never run out of challenges to conquer.

Of course, the heart and soul of Counter-Strike 2 lie in its intense, skill-based combat. The gunplay is as tight and responsive as ever, rewarding precision and strategy over mindless spraying and praying. Whether you're engaging in heart-pounding firefights with friends or testing your mettle against skilled opponents in competitive matchmaking, every kill feels earned, making victory all the sweeter.

But perhaps what sets Counter-Strike 2 apart from its predecessors is its commitment to community engagement. With robust modding tools and support for user-generated content, the game empowers players to unleash their creativity and shape the future of the franchise. From custom maps and game modes to community-run tournaments and events, the possibilities are endless, ensuring that Counter-Strike 2 remains a vibrant and thriving community for years to come.

In conclusion, Counter-Strike 2: Evolved Warfare is a triumph of modern gaming. With its stunning visuals, innovative gameplay features, and unwavering dedication to its community, it sets a new standard for the first-person shooter genre. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer looking for your next gaming obsession, Counter-Strike 2 is an experience you won't soon forget.

162665032.review:
CS2: A Familiar Thrill with a Modern Twist
As a seasoned Counter-Strike player with over 12,000 hours invested in the classic CS 1.6, I approached CS2 with a mix of excitement and skepticism. Could a new iteration capture the essence of the original while introducing fresh elements?

The Good: A Great Game
CS2 doesn’t disappoint. The core gameplay remains faithful to its roots: intense firefights, strategic team dynamics, and adrenaline-pumping rounds. The familiar maps, weapons, and bomb defusal scenarios evoke nostalgia, transporting me back to those late nights in cyber cafes.

The graphics have received a much-needed upgrade, and the sound design is immersive. The gunplay feels crisp, and the movement mechanics are spot-on. Whether I’m clutching a round or coordinating with teammates, the rush is real.

The Uncanny Familiarity
What surprised me most was how CS2 managed to retain that nostalgic magic. Despite being a new game, it feels like slipping into a well-worn pair of sneakers—the fit is just right. The muscle memory from countless 1.6 matches kicks in, and I find myself instinctively trying to bunny-hopping around corners.

The Bitter Pill: Cheaters
However, there’s a dark cloud over this otherwise sunny battlefield: cheaters. They infest the servers like a relentless virus. Aimbots, wallhacks, and other nefarious tools tarnish the experience. It’s disheartening to see fair matches disrupted by those who prioritise victory over integrity.

Valve, please take note: The community needs better anti-cheat measures. We want to enjoy CS2 without constantly questioning opponents’ legitimacy.

Final Verdict
CS2 is a worthy successor, bridging the gap between nostalgia and modernity. If you loved CS 1.6 (I don't know how cs:go was), you’ll feel right at home. Just be prepared to encounter a few bad apples along the way. Let’s hope the developers tighten security to preserve the spirit of fair competition.

P.S. To my fellow players: Let’s keep the spirit alive, report cheaters, and make CS2 a better place for everyone! 🎮🔫

162616755.review:
I really love Counter-Strike. I loved CS:GO, and I love the idea of CS:2.

Why is this review bad? Because VALVE fucked up the execution of this idea so bad that It's kinda hard to believe.

1. The Anti-Cheat. It is literally not existent. There are cheaters EVERYWHERE in higher ranks. At launch there were tons of false bans which is what leads me to believe that VALVE disabled the AC until they can make sure that no one is getting falsely banned anymore. Unfortunately this results in spinbotters, aimhackers, wallhackers and bhop-scripters going absolutely wild in comp, premiere and wingman. There are people SPRAYING the AWP and teleporting to the second bomb site in wingman... How is that even possible???

2. The net code. It's bad. Really bad. There is rubber banding, faulty hit reg, the tagging teleports you back from behind cover, movement feels off, and I'm sure there is more that I missed.

3. The Servers. They're now hardcoded to 64 tick afaik., they lag BADLY sometimes. I've had people just teleporting all over the place (this was visible to everyone, not just me), there is constant package loss, downloading demos is buggy sometimes, the subtick system doesn't solve shit (in fact the gameplay feels SO MUCH worse than in any other shooter).

4. The Linux build. VALVE is known to care A LOT about Linux support and so do I. To say that I was disappointed when I first fired up CS:2 on my Linux powered gaming PC would be an understatement. CS:GO's Linux build was flawless. It was better than the Windows build (especially when it comes to performance). But CS:2? Sound didn't work, performance is STILL unacceptable, sound will sometimes vanish in the middle of a game and for some people the game didn't even start up.

Another fun one is that on certain Mesa versions smokes are invisible! Free and undetectable wallhacks for everyone with and Intel or AMD GPU! Oh wait, the game doesn't work properly on Intel GPUs... I believe this is also the case on Windows so screw Arc users I guess.

5. The WIndows build. You thought VALVE wouldn't fuck up the Windows build? Apparently you're wrong. I don't run the Windows built myself so I can only speak for some of my friends who are running Windows. Apparently it's really unstable. A friend of mine constantly experienced crashes, others had awful performance (just like I have on the Linux build), and Radeon users had a really bad time with shader stutter (at least VALVE fixed that one now).

6. Content. I'm not gonna make a detailed list here, basically CS:2 is missing 60% of CS:GO's content. I'm talking maps, player models, modes, even features and console commands (rip cl_righthand 0...).

NOTE: Left handed view models are back! Game still sux tho.

7. The discontinuation of CS:GO. I wouldn't be so mad if VALVE just gave us the option to continue to play the better CS (CS:GO). Unfortunately, they don't give us this option. Match making is gone and community Servers are almost always completely empty (if you can even find a working one). The Server browser if fucked because it shows both CS:GO and CS:2 Servers and setting up a community Server yourself requires an obscure sourcemods plugin to un-fuck the lobby system. Otherwise no one can join the Server if you disable LAN mode. (The plugin is called NoLobbyReservation).

I know why VALVE did it. But I honestly do not care. If CS:2 is so bad that nobody will play it if they have the option, then it should not be released. Stop forcing this garbage onto us and let us play CS:GO again until you managed to make CS:2 as playable as the other Counter-Strike titles.

162591302.review:
I tried to get into this game. I really tried for a whole 36 hours to try and see what it is that so many others like about it. But unfortunately, I could not see anything appealing about it whatsoever.

The game is essentially a boomer shooter that tries to be tactical and fails, instead creating a meta-based shooter that requires hours of grinding and practice for this one specific game to be good at it. And that's not really not my issue with it either. That's just a negative criticism of it. My issue with it is the fact that its a dated game with technologies and design principles that belong in the 90s dressed up to look modern and somehow, the fans eat it all up and swear by it.

The concept of this game is actually quite fresh, so much so, that its very unique even today. The fact that there are opposing sides with differing, clashing objectives with their own unique advantages and disadvantages that are still balanced out by their own field performance with the use of the economy system. The concept of this game was revolutionary when it came out and it still remains unique to this very day. The only other game that has ever implemented this concept has to be Valorant and there is no other rival for CS, really.

However, this amazing concept goes down the drain because of the way things are handled and implemented in the game. The technologies felt dated to me back when I first played one of the CS franchise games back in 2007, albeit they felt more modern back then. But when I play this game today, nothing has really changed about the game over the ages. It's still the same old Counter Strike just updated with modern graphics and textures and that's pretty much it. The only advancement that this game has comes by way of visual aesthetics. And with the CS2 update, they have finally mastered the art of Volumetric Smoke, something that the world had already begun implementing in their games more than a decade ago.

The rest of the technologies remain practically the same as they were with the original game that came out back in the 2000s. They still use a static recoil pattern that they expect players to drill into their muscle memory. Even the gun doesn't bounce around and there typically aren't a whole lot of tracers that tell you where your shot is going. Delta Force from 1998 had dynamic recoil patterns and bullet velocities down, but somehow, 26 years later, Valve still doesn't want to do it despite all the other games having that very thing. The only time you'll find some semblance of recoil is when you're scoped in. Then there are the point object  players in this game. While most modern shooters, especially tactical shooters use actual ragdoll physics for their players, CSGO sticks to the old point physics for players to move their own characters instead. This allows them to climb onto walls and ledges like a goat that a typical military operator or terrorist would never be able to climb or go through in real life. For a game that clearly tries to be tactical, this is a huge oversight that only reinforces the meta gaming nature of this game.

Somethign else that makes this game heavily dependent on said Metas are the maps. To comment on the maps themselves, they are not the best at any rate. The angles are odd and awkward for a competitive shooter, but at least they are realistic. Despite that, there a whole lot of underutilised empty space thhat serves almost no purpose except for a transit from point A to point B. One can say that this reinforces a more strategic approach to the game as players must work as a team to utilise proper offensive and defensive strategies before every round. And that's yet again, a wonderful concept if the game hadn't already been ruined by the metas. And the primary reason for that is the fact that the maps are overplayed and run through, having received next to no updates since the year 2000 when the game first came out. And even then, the updates that have been rolled out only seek to remove some of the metas that the players heavily rely on that Valve thought are exploitative in nature. In any other game, these metas would, in fact, be called exploits. What Valve needs to realise is the fact that when players have been playing the same maps over and over again for the past quarter of a century, they will figure out how to exploit every nook and cranny of the map to gain an advantage. And that's exactly what the players are doing. They've figured out how to exploit the metas to win and it has become a game of just that.

People like to say that CS is a skill based shooter, and honestly, it's not. Skill is definitely a factor in the game, but it's far more about practicing the metas and committing them to memory than it is about skills or tactics. You can't always out-skill an unfair meta and tactics don't really work out that well when there really aren't a whole lot of features on the map to exploit said tactics. At least the team based strategy aspect of the game still manages to work out to a degree. I can dominate a deathmatch or an arms race but I can't do the same in a typical bomb defusal scenario since folks don't know how to leverage the metas in the former whereas they know exaactly how to do so in the latter. New players practically need a guide that is experienced with all the metas of the game to show them how to play it and then they need to grind countless hours into perfecting them just so that they can finally begin playing the game effectively. That is not common behaviour for a multiplayer game. You only get to see this in a handful of games that are complex, and given the lack of complexity to CS, it's a surprise that this is a thing until you're faced with all the metas. Valve is seemingly so afraid of changing this game that they're practically running it into the ground despite the fanbase vehemently coming out in support of it.

CS is a franchise that is in dire need of modernisation. And the way to achieve that is by changing the formula that they're using for their competitive scene and shifting things around drastically. That's something that Valve is seemingly afraid of doing. The way towards modernisation and remaining up to date does NOT come by way of trying to copy other games by adding Danger Zone to your game. That albeit a fresh change of pace, felt like a subpar Call of Duty clone. By this point, I feel like I've drilled my point in quite a bit. The mechanics and maps are outdated and the whole culture in CS has become one of drilling metas so that you can play it properly by exploiting said metas. Some of the game mechanics such as fixed recoil patterns and the point physics even reinforce this very behaviour. If anything, CS is modern game only as far as the graphics are concerned. Everything else about it is terribly dated and I have no idea why the fans love to slurp it all up.

162491190.review:
Nostalgia for Counter-Strike 1.6, and over time, for CSGO, fuels my desire to play this legendary game. But why do I give it a poor rating, you might ask? I'll try to answer briefly, though it won't be short anyway. The thing is, this game is like a beloved dish you crave to enjoy, but there's always something wrong with it: either it's too raw, underseasoned, or instead of salt, they added sugar, and every time, you simply can't fully enjoy it due to someone else's cooking mistakes! More specific examples of problems are as follows: the shooting mechanics in the game are quite difficult; the simple logic of aiming and shooting in this game is flawed, and if you say "that's part of the challenge," you're wrong - often, you'll see how you can aim at a target 30 meters away and end up hitting the ground near your feet, defying the laws of physics. Eventually, you might get used to this kind of shooting and hone your skills over time, BUT the random effect undermines this refined shooting system. Look at the pro scene; even pro players often fail due to "It didn't hit", meaning the same random effect interfered with their shooting skills, which is impossible to overcome. 
And now, delving deeper into the mire, after playing this game (aside from LAN), you'll often encounter hit registration problems that have almost never been fixed since CSGO times, often simply being ignored. If at the beginning of your tough player journey you don't feel this pain, the more you face strong opponents, the more important your shots will become, determining the fate of rounds or even the entire game. Imagine this: a challenging match where you're carrying your whole team, and then that moment when you're about to achieve an ace and hear applause from your teammates... But the server tells you, 'Sorry, your AWP shot didn't register, better luck next time,' and you lose because of an unregistered hit. That's the moment of intense pain. And yes, you can't solve the hit registration problem no matter how rarely it occurs.
The next problem with the game, not just in LAN, will be the same hit registration issues, but often against you. This is a perfect method of inflicting pain, real pain. Imagine a situation where you dash behind a wall, and suddenly you're an unreachable target for the enemy, but BAM, congratulations, you're dead; a hit is registered a meter behind you. The feeling in that moment is impossible to convey. And with this, you can't do anything; again, even if this phenomenon doesn't happen often.
Let's talk about CHEATERS in this game separately. The damned cheaters don't let you enjoy the game, and thanks to them, you'll again experience large doses of real pain. The frustration is incredible. And you can't do anything about cheaters because the reporting system from Valve works like a bicycle without wheels: no matter how much you pedal, you can't get anywhere. It seems like there's hardly any fight against cheaters in this game; it appears that the developers have simply given up on it.
I still have a lot more I want to mention in this review, but instead of writing it all to you, I have an endless desire to jab someone in the ribs. Primarily, I want to jab to cheaters who turn this game into a dumpster, and secondarily, I want to jab the developers who do almost NOTHING about the numerous problems in the game.
The game is cool; at first, I wanted to write a good review, but then I remembered that it's still Counter-Strike 2, not Counter-Strike 1.6.

This is honestly one of the hardest games I have ever played. I rage at it. I say I hate it. I want to delete it. However, through the rage, it really does come down to being a "skill issue," which I respect so much. The fact that I actually have to play to get better to achieve a better play-style instead of relying on some broken meta is so cool and fun to me. I heard someone say this game is like chess with guns. That probably is the best way to describe this game. I suck at this game, but the more I play, the more I notice tiny little advancements in my gameplay. That to me is a true multiplayer game. Through playing and learning maps, angles, guns, different situations, etc. you can really have some fun with this game. One of my current favorite multiplayer games that I want to strive to get better in. 

I recommend it to anyone who wants a challenge and is eager to learn a new shooter that takes skill and patience.

162398631.review:
As an avid fan of competitive shooters, I find it necessary to address the stark differences between Valorant and Counter Strike 2. Valorant, while attempting to innovate within the genre, falls embarrassingly short when compared to the timeless masterpiece that is Counter Strike 2. One of the primary shortcomings of Valorant lies in its lackluster gameplay mechanics. The clunky movement and unresponsive gunplay make for an unsatisfying experience, especially when juxtaposed with the fluidity and precision of Counter Strike 2. Additionally, Valorant's reliance on character abilities disrupts the purity of skill-based gameplay that Counter Strike 2 epitomizes, introducing an unnecessary layer of complexity that detracts from the core shooting mechanics.

Furthermore, the design philosophy behind Valorant's maps pales in comparison to the meticulously crafted layouts of Counter Strike 2. While Counter Strike 2 maps are ingeniously balanced and provide ample opportunities for strategic play, Valorant's maps feel uninspired and lack the intricate details that contribute to dynamic gameplay scenarios. The result is a tedious and repetitive experience that fails to captivate players in the same way that Counter Strike 2's maps do, where every corner and chokepoint is meticulously designed to facilitate intense and strategic encounters.

Lastly, the lack of a vibrant and thriving esports scene in Valorant further solidifies its inferiority to Counter Strike 2. Despite Riot Games' efforts to promote Valorant as a competitive esport, it has failed to garner the same level of excitement and engagement as Counter Strike 2 tournaments. Counter Strike 2's rich legacy in the esports realm, coupled with its time-tested gameplay mechanics and dedicated community, cements its status as the superior choice for fans of competitive shooters. In conclusion, Valorant may have attempted to emulate the success of Counter Strike 2, but it ultimately falls short in nearly every aspect, making it an absolute disappointment for those seeking a true competitive gaming experience.

In terms of gameplay, it takes teamwork and map knowledge in order to consistently win matches.  For a long time, I disliked Counter Strike  because I did not understand the mechanics of the game well. After sinking more hours into the game, I realized that Counter Strike has a high skill gap, and that there is a ton to learn. Now that I am older, I enjoy this aspect of CS2. In all, I would recommend anyone interested in S&D or R6 to try this game if you have not already. I believe this is what those modes/games aspire to be. Enjoy the original recipe.
